ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR
1ST APRIL, 2011 TO 31ST MARCH, 2012

 

(Paper Cmd. 1 of 2011)

 

          Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [4th Allotted Day].

 

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

 

    

     Head M – Ministry of Finance   

    

     Question again proposed.

 

 

Whole-of-Government

 

     Ms Jessica Tan Soon Neo (East Coast): Sir, I beg to move,

 

     That the total sum to be allocated for Head M of the Estimates be reduced by $100.

     Over the last week, as we debated Budget 2011 and in the various

Column: 3845

Committee of Supply discussions, the focus has been on productivity and building capability.  As Minister Tharman has said, we are stepping up investments to transform Singapore into a high-capability economy and a global city that stands out for its liveability.  So can Minister share how effective public agencies have been in achieving productivity gains?

 

     In December 2010, in the Singapore Public Sector outcome review, the Government outlined six broad strategies to take Singapore forward and how public agencies can work together to achieve these goals.  The report recognised the need for the whole-of-Government approach to tackle issues rather than having each agency deal with a specific area.  While agencies are effective and efficient in each of the areas of responsibility and competency, there is an increasing need to work across agencies to address the complexity of situations and scenarios that face us at the national and at the citizen level. 

 

     Can the Minister share the progress that the Government has made to drive the whole-of-Government approach to achieve the strategic outcomes for effective citizen services and national issues?  What measures have been put in place to ensure accountability across agencies?

 

     In the Budget debate, I had raised a question on our fiscal position given the several large projects in the pipeline: projects announced by the Government from our transport infrastructure, upgrading projects to rejuvenating our heartlands, our lifestyle projects and investments to further improve our health and educational systems to serve the need of Singaporeans. 

 

     Our expenditures have increased to 14.5% of GDP in the last five years.  As

Column: 3846

Minister had shared in the Budget Statement, our expenditures are expected to increase further to 16.5% of GDP over the next five years.  These projects are large and complex requiring sizeable financial commitments over the next five years.  Can Minister share the measures put in place to ensure strong management of these projects to achieve intended outcomes and meeting fiscal accountabilities?  How will fiscal disciplines be maintained while allowing for flexibility in the approach?  Many of these projects are multi-year and, as we all know, the requirements will change and will need to be incorporated while managed effectively to ensure that the intended outcomes are achieved. 

 

     Many of these projects will also require the whole-of-Government approach as they will involve multi-agencies to achieve the outcome.  For example, the Remaking Our Heartland (ROH) projects will involve HDB, LTA, NParks, PUB, NEA, the Sports Council and even the Heritage Board, to name a few.  What is in place to facilitate this collaboration and ensure effective and productive use of resources?  How would we track our progress towards achieving the outcomes outlined in the Singapore Public Sector outcome review?  What will the indicators of success be, as we are looking over a multi-year period?

 

Fiscal prudence

 

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (Marine Parade): Sir, it is widely known that our Civil Service is held in high regard by both the public as well as its counterparts in the region and other parts of the world.  However, one feedback from the citizenry we hear from time to time has been on occasions, public funds have not been well accounted for in some of the Ministries with procedures that can be further improved.  There were also occasions when Ministries have overspent their

Column: 3847

budget for projects, such as the recent Youth Olympic Games, and evidence of wastage has been detected during audit exercises.  When such incidents are reported in the press, it affects public confidence in our processes.

 

     As such, I would like to ask the Minister, what are the initiatives for instilling discipline within public agencies?  What measures are taken when there are instances of over expenditure from the amount budgeted for? 

 

     Another related issue is with regards to the management of mega projects.  In recent years, I can see that public development projects are getting larger and more complex.  These include the development of the new MRT lines which may need to go deeper underground and are more complex.  I would like to ask the Minister if there is a framework in place to ensure proper and prudent management of these mega projects.  Perhaps the Minister can also share with the House examples of such measures.

 

Collaboration through e-Government

 

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah): Chairman, I would like to declare my interest as the company I work for bids and engages in e-Government projects.  I represent the GPC in fielding this cut. 

 

     The Government has always been seen as a leader in e-government initiatives.  With more Singaporeans being connected and having greater interest to have a say in their well-being, there is an opportunity to use the Internet and social media to better engage and collaborate with citizens.

 

     Can the Ministry elaborate on new services that it plans to deliver for citizens?  What can Singaporeans look forward to better engage, share ideas and better collaborate with the Government?  I elaborated in my Budget speech that this

Column: 3848

is the best opportunity for the Government to truly connect with the young but we must also work hard at the messaging, packaging and communications aspects to truly connect and garner buy-in; not just spend on Web2.0 technologies and infrastructure.

 

     I hope that the Ministry is planning on ensuring that we also have sufficiently trained personnel who understand our policies and can engage effectively with members of the public.  How does the Ministry improve measures and training for officers to minimise mistakes online, such as the recent case where an HPB officer mistakenly published his personal message on a Government platform?

 

     How has the Ministry performed in improving productivity across the Government through better automation and integration in recent years?  Can the Government share some statistics on achieved cost-savings and efficiency through large projects and economies of scale projects, such as SOEasy?  In this, I also hope that the Government sets an example for the industry to practise best-sourcing for innovation, rather than solely on cheapest price.

 

Income tax of sole proprietors and limited liability partnerships

 

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio): Chairman, Sir, shaping our nation into a regional and global business and investment hub has always been high on the Government's agenda.  Rightly so, because this would translate to greater opportunities to develop more industries on home ground which in turn promotes a flourishing business economy.  In recent years, the Government has also been encouraging more people to take the journey to entrepreneurship by equipping them with the know-how and making loans more accessible to them.  In running a business, the annual income tax payable

Column: 3849

is one item that must not be overlooked as it can add up to quite a significant figure.  For Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) companies, profits are distributed among partners and tax based on each partner's personal income tax rates.  The current income tax rate for top bracket income is 20%.  A private limited company, on the other hand, is taxed at corporate tax rate which is currently capped at 17%.  In addition, they enjoy various other tax exemptions where applicable. 

 

     This means that they invariably pay lower taxes than successful sole proprietors and limited liability partners.  This may impose an undue burden on sole proprietors and limited liability companies which are receiving less Government support and yet are exposed to the same risks and turbulence of a market economy as any private limited company.  Also, sole proprietorship and LLPs are less expensive to set up compared to a private limited company.  It is precisely for this reason that some budding entrepreneurs are attracted to set up their companies under LLP. 

 

     Hence, I urge the Minister to make the income tax system fairer and more equitable for sole proprietors and LLP companies.  An example of how this could be done, perhaps, is to subject sole proprietors and LLP partners to be taxed not higher than the corporate tax rates.  I hope Minister can give a favourable review on the tax system.

 

Business-friendly processes

 

     Ms Jessica Tan Soon Neo: Mr Chairman, Singapore remains one of the world's most competitive economies according to several reputable rankings.  The World Bank has, for the last five years, ranked Singapore as the best place to do business.  In early 2010, Singapore

Column: 3850

was also ranked as the most competitive economy in the world by Switzerland's IMD Business School in its 2010 World Competitiveness Yearbook, ahead of Hong Kong and the US, highlighting Singapore's resilience through the financial crisis despite the challenges on the volatile economic conditions we faced. 

 

     The World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 2010/2011 has also recognised Singapore as the third most competitive economy in the world, after Switzerland and Sweden, and Asia's most competitive economy with our strong institutional environment, market efficiencies and quality infrastructure. 

 

     Singapore was ranked highly for our goods and labour market efficiency and our financial market sophistication.  It has, however, highlighted that to further strengthen Singapore's competitiveness, there could be stronger adoption of the latest technologies and policies to enhance the sophistication of our companies.

 

     Switzerland's economy, which is ranked first, is characterised by an excellent capacity for innovation and very sophisticated business culture.  It has high spending on R&D and its scientific research institutions are among the world's best.  The strong collaboration between academia and business sectors ensures that much of the research is translated into marketable products and processes reinforced by strong intellectual property protection. 

 

     So, can Minister share the various pro-business measures that are in place to continue to foster a favourable business environment to support businesses operating in Singapore?  While we continue to drive business-friendly processes and simplification for businesses to operate in Singapore, what more can be done to enable a competitive and conducive business environment to support greater

Column: 3851

innovation and sophistication of our companies and make Singapore the most competitive economy, both in Asia and globally?

 

Export-Import (EXIM) Bank

 

     Mr Teo Siong Seng (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, and Members of Parliament, good afternoon.  First, I would like to declare that I am the President of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry, President of the Singapore Shipping Association and Managing Director of Pacific International Lines.

 

     The notion of an EXIM Bank for cross-border financing was brought up by the Economic Strategies Committee and then again in Budget 2010.  Since then, the business community, especially the SMEs, had been looking forward to good news on the setting up of such a specialised institution.  The setting up of an EXIM Bank would be highly useful in serving the needs of SMEs intending to spread their wings into emerging markets.

 

     After listening to the 2011 Budget Statement, SMEs cannot help but feel disappointed.  I speak on behalf of SME owners who expressed dismay upon learning that the Government has decided against setting up a dedicated trade finance institution.  This was only disclosed after a whole year had gone by.  Instead, we were told that the Government would work with existing specialists and providers to provide such a service to SMEs.

 

 

Again, there is no real certainty on the details as the Government will only provide an update in the latter half of 2011.

 

12.15 pm

 

     I note that the Government plans to work with commercial players to set up this specialised institution for cross-border financing.  This is likely to work at cross

Column: 3852

purposes.  Existing specialist providers are driven by commercial considerations and are reluctant to provide financing for overseas projects bearing a higher element of risk.  Currently, SMEs with the resolve and intention to embark on viable projects in emerging markets find themselves in a dilemma.  They are strapped by the inability to secure financing from risk-averse commercial banks.  Having no track record is viewed as a major constraint by the banks.  Thus, the prospect of an independent EXIM Bank to support their overseas ventures seems to provide a glimmer of hope.

 

     Again, let me cite the case of WEC Engineers & Constructors Pte Ltd, which I brought up in the Budget debate last year.  WEC’s core business is in the aviation and jet fuel system.  The company had applied for IE Singapore’s Internationalisation Finance Scheme, where IE Singapore’s portion of risk sharing is 70% while the participating financial institution's (PFI) portion is 30%.  However, because WEC is an SME, the PFI demanded that the company should undertake additional co-sharing of default risks.  Overseas ventures require a healthy cash flow, and this additional co-sharing ties up their liquidity funds.

 

     WEC also heeded the Government’s call to develop overseas markets, and are currently bidding for two projects in Indo-China. Overseas projects are far larger in scope than those in Singapore’s small domestic market, and thus, require additional financial assistance. This is extremely difficult to secure through commercially-driven financial institutions.

 

     Venturing overseas is not for the faint-hearted.  Businessmen and entrepreneurs need to have big dreams.  At the same time, substantial financial resources need to be invested before these dreams can be a reality.  The ideal scenario would be to combine private enterprise with Government support.  In this case, Government support

Column: 3853

in the form of an EXIM bank was considered essential and important.

 

     I raised this same concern during the Budget debate last year, and continued to ask for an update on the setting up of an EXIM bank in a subsequent Parliament session in May last year.

 

     We are experiencing increasing volatility in various regions today.  As Minister had mentioned at the beginning of his Budget speech, the external condition has become more complex.  Last year, the concerns were on the sovereign debt crisis in Europe. This year, the Middle East and North Africa are being affected by revolts and toppled regimes.  This would definitely affect the cost of borrowing in private financial institutions.

 

     If SMEs were to rely on traditional banking channels, they are unlikely to make any headway in the current market.  A full-fledged, dedicated EXIM bank to support cross-border financing would have addressed this need.  This vehicle would then take a long-term view of overseas investments instead of shying away from financial support to fuel business expansion.  We are concerned that further delays on setting up such a financial vehicle would become a precious opportunity cost for SMEs.

 

     I would also like to discuss how an EXIM Bank could help to develop the maritime sector, which has been identified as one of Singapore’s strategic business sectors.  Based on industry feedback, shipping banks in Singapore are not as competitive as EXIM banks.  They rarely lend to companies beyond a five-year tenure and often require vessels as mortgages and collateral.

 

     Export-Import institutions in China and South Korea are more willing to lend on commercial terms and provide liquidity to

Column: 3854

shipowners.  Even though there are certain strings attached to the loans, such as building the vessels at their yards, they can provide up to 70% financing. In fact, it was just reported on the 4th of March that the EXIM Bank of Korea, the state-run lender known as Kexim, will be boosting its 2011 fund-raising target by about 10%, to finance more shipbuilding orders.

 

     Banks in Singapore might be uncomfortable with taking up such exposures, especically for financing of rigs and FPSOs.  Banks tend to shy away from financing due to the huge amount of money involved and the risk deemed involved with the oil businesses.

 

     If such an EXIM bank were to be set up in Singapore, it could be tied to activities like building rigs and FPSOs at yards in Singapore, which is a booming sector here.  By doing so, we can not only develop Singapore as a ship financing centre, but truly become a one-stop International Maritime Centre.

 

     On the topic of financing for SMEs, I would also like to touch upon the Co-Investment Programme for SMEs.  Under Phase One of this programme launched in December last year, the Government will provide up to $250 million in capital to grow local firms into globally competitive players.  This would be matched by private equity fund managers.  It is envisaged that about $200 million will go to promising SMEs with annual revenues of less than $100 million.

 

     The Co-Investment Programme will be administered by private equity fund managers.  In order to ensure that promising SMEs benefit from this programme, I hope the Government would provide special consideration or added incentives to encourage these fund managers to assist new and innovative SMEs.  These new and innovative SMEs are likely to venture into fast-growing new

Column: 3855

industries or traditional industries with new growth potential. 

 

     Ultimately, SMEs should find faster and easier access to capital, so that they could survive, thrive and contribute even more to our economy.

 

Developing capability in accountancy sector

 

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim: Sir, the accountancy sector plays a significant role in providing access to talent and professional accountancy services required by our economy.  In April 2010, the Committee to Develop the Accountancy Sector (CDAS) proposed 10 recommendations to broaden the talent pool and deepen expertise in the accounting sector to transform Singapore into a leading global accountancy hub for Asia Pacific by 2020.  I find that the report provides credible and good recommendations, as well as directions in helping us to build capabilities in the accounting sector.  I would like to ask the Minister for an update on the progress made in implementing the recommendations made by CDAS.  What are the challenges that we are likely to face in our quest to be a global accountancy hub and how are we going to address these challenges?

 

Singapore as a global accountancy hub

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Chairman, Singapore serves as a global and regional hub for several international companies.  In the borderless global economy, accounting practices are being outsourced.  Singapore is blessed with an excellent financial regulatory framework and skilled accounting practitioners and is an excellent choice for the setting up of a global accountancy hub.  I will be grateful if the Ministry could provide an update on its initiatives to transform Singapore into a leading global accountancy hub.  What is the outcome of efforts to attract

Column: 3856

accounting professionals?  What is the supply and demand situation for accounting professionals in the current job market?  How is the sector managing the salary pricing of these accounting professionals?

 

     Chairman, I am also keen to know the proportion of business derived by Singapore-based accounting firms from overseas last year.  Of the overseas business, what proportion was derived from China and India, compared to other countries in the region?

 

 

     Mr Speaker: Mr Teo Ser Luck. You have four cuts, take them together please.

CPA designation

 

Accountancy sector development fund

 

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports and Minister for Transport (Mr Teo Ser Luck): Sir, I declare my interest as the advisor to the Institute of Certified Public Accountants of Singapore (ICPAS).  The Asia Pacific accountancy market is the fastest growing market for international accountancy networks.  This market is targeted to hit US$38 billion in the next few years, and this presents a compelling value proposition and opportunities for Singapore's accountancy sector. 

 

     I support the recommendations of Committee to Develop the Accountancy Sector (CDAS).  The need for strong infrastructure and concerted action by key stakeholders and institutions to support the growth and development of the sector is of utmost importance.  The services sector has been identified as one of the key economic drivers.  I am glad to know that the accountancy sector is on its radar screen and the $10 million fund would be

Column: 3857

injected to develop the capabilities of the sector.  I would like to ask the Minister to elaborate on the specific plans for this $10 million fund.

 

     ICPAS has a membership of 23,000 and has an integral role to play in the development of the accountancy sector. These members include both practising and non-practising ones, and they carry with them a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) designation.  This designation is a form of recognition for their qualification, experience and professionalism.  I fully support the CDAS's recommendation to have a new professional qualification examination to qualify CPAs.  This will ensure we keep to the high standards of the profession and level up to the international accountancy bodies of the world.  I would like to ask the Minister: with the new professional accountancy programme, will there be any change to the CPA designation?  What will happen to the current ICPAS members and how will it affect the current cohort of accountancy students in the three universities?

 

     The institute must play a committed and concerted role to support and partner the Government in its efforts to develop the accountancy sector.  It must also widen and deepen its mission of leading, developing and supporting accountancy professionals, and contribute in developing Singapore as an accountancy hub for Asia.  CDAS has recommended that the ICPAS be transformed into a professional body with global membership, outlook and standing.  It outlines two key strategic areas for ICPAS to undertake and achieve these goals.

 

     I understand that ICPAS is in the process of reviewing its constitution to ensure that the constitution will be aligned and relevant to its mission as a national accountancy body.  This will include changing leadership structure and

Column: 3858

renewal, which will include a maximum tenure for the presidency, lower the average age of the membership and office bearers, and strengthen governance structure and systems.  I am aware that ICPAS is expected to complete the review of the relevant recommendations of its constitutions within six months.  This will also ensure that ICPAS will realise its mission and vision and strongly support the Government's effort to transform Singapore into a leading and global accountancy hub for Asia Pacific.

 

     It is of importance that a transformed ICPAS will see the widening and deepening of its talent pool as well.  This will catalyse and multiply ideas and spur innovation to cater to higher expectations, a more sophisticated economy, keener international competition, and more complex issues.  If ICPAS is to transform itself and align objectives in implementing CDA's recommendations today, it must work with the Singapore Accountancy Council (SAC), to be set up, very closely.  However, the SAC's scope of work and responsibilities are still unclear.  I would like to ask the Minister what is the SAC's role in comparison to ICPAS? Will both entities be complementary?

 

 

     The Second Minister for Finance (Mrs Lim Hwee Hua): Mr Chairman, Sir, first, let me thank hon. Members for their comments and suggestions.  Given the time constraints, I shall highlight the key intent of the relevant policies and address specific comments whenever possible.

 

     The questions that Members have raised centered on three areas which I shall address in turn.  First, leading a high-performance and accountable Government.  Secondly, fostering a favourable environment for business.  Thirdly, building capabilities in the accountancy sector.

 

     Sir, my Ministry will continue with our efforts to build a high-performance Government that is accountable to

Column: 3859

Singaporeans.  We adopt a three-pronged approach.  First, we will promote whole-of-Government strategic outcomes, by addressing important challenges and opportunities that cut across agencies or Ministry boundaries.

 

     Second, we will inculcate a mindset of fiscal prudence amongst all our agencies to various measures to promote value-for-money practices.

 

     Third, we will build a collaborative Government in the delivering of e-services, so as to tap the potential technology to improve government service delivery with the Government working hand-in-hand with the private and people sectors.

 

     Ms Jessica Tan asked about the progress the Government has made in driving strategic outcomes through the whole-of-Government approach. As policy issues become increasingly complex and cut across traditional Ministry boundaries, the need to augment the current approach to inter-agency collaboration has become even more pressing.  Our public agencies have increasingly to work together as one networked Government to address strategic challenges.  For the Ministry of Finance, this means that we have to access outcomes holistically from the whole-of-Government's perspective, and not compartmentalised by individual Ministries in order to allocate funds to achieve the best outcomes for Singapore.  The Singapore Public Sector Outcomes Review (SPOR) which was published by the Ministry in December last year captures this intent.  It takes stock of the collective efforts by the different Government Ministries acting together beyond the individual Ministry remit to address strategic challenges facing our nation and assess the progress that has been made thus far. This collective effort to monitor current and emerging policy issues guides our strategies and resource allocation for the future.

 

Column: 3860

12.30 pm

 

     Notwithstanding the inherent difficulty of coordinating efforts across agencies, the report shows that Singapore has done well overall.  How do we assess this?  We look at the outcomes.  Our economy remains internationally competitive, more people are satisfied with the local living and working environment and Singaporeans are proud of our nation. 

 

     Let me now illustrate with three examples of what is meant by promoting whole-of-Government outcomes.  The first example relates to public satisfaction with Singapore's living environment over the years.  In 2003, 70% of the public was satisfied with Singapore's living, working and leisure environment.  In 2009, this rose to more than 83%.  This achievement was a result of collective efforts made by a number of our agencies to enhance the quality of life in Singapore in very much the same way that Ms Jessica Tan has described.  Some of these initiatives include the renewal of our public and private housing estates, the development of surrounding recreational areas such as the Southern Ridges and the Changi Waterfront, the beautifying and landscaping of the waterways and reservoirs under the Active, Beautiful and Clean Waters programme, and the promotion of arts and culture such as the building of the National Art Gallery.  Singapore is now well regarded internationally as a more vibrant city to live, work and play.

     Like most Singaporeans, I am very proud that our education system is like that.  The message to students is that all you need to do is to work hard, because the system will let you go as far as you are capable of, regardless of your family background and circumstances.  Does this message continue to hold true today?  To a large extent, the answer is “yes”.  Whether you live in a bungalow or rental flat, it is the same PSLE examinations that you have to clear, same “O” levels that you have to take to determine which Junior College or polytechnic you can be enrolled in, the same “A” levels that will decide how much choice you have for university and course selection.

     Social mobility stands at the heart of our education processes, and indeed, our whole-of-Government policies.  My colleagues will deal with specific issues later but I would like to deal with this squarely.  I think it is important enough.


     From 1960 to 2010, Singapore's per capita nominal GDP rose 100-fold, from US$400 to more than US$40,000 today.  Nice number to remember.  This remarkable achievement has been variously depicted.  Monikers abound, and Members would be familiar with them: "sleepy fishing village to world-class hub", "colonial backwater to economic powerhouse", "Third World to First", etc.

 

     But for me, "The Singapore Story" probably best captures this economic transformation.  It was a massive rising tide that lifted all boats, with a reach that extended deep into the heartlands.  Stagnant pools turned into thriving waterways as the tidal rise was sustained over 40-odd years.


     As a result, social mobility occurred en masse  – and this is important – both of Singapore compared to other countries and within the society.  Both elements are important – of the entire country and the people within it.  There were remarkable improvements in almost all conventional measures of living standards, indeed, we were physically transformed – not only

the city landscape but its people too, literally!  What do I mean?


     I witnessed this profound change, this phenomenon, on our people physically as a young doctor.  Due to better nutrition, children grew taller and heavier.  When we started out as medical students, we referred to height-weight charts and as we went to the wards, we realised they were no longer applicable because our children were already way off the charts.  Height-weight charts based on older cohorts became obsolete and had to be revised and adjusted periodically.

 

     With widespread public sanitation and vaccination programmes, disease patterns changed.  I started as a medical student seeing some infectious diseases which were typical of poorly developed countries but as I aged and progressed in my training, they changed to diabetes and heart diseases associated with affluent societies.  Infant mortality rates, which represent a very useful indicator of general healthcare standards, dived to one of the lowest in the world.  In short, more babies lived, grew taller and bigger; adults acquired affluent diseases born of richer lifestyles even as they lived longer – a profound change.


     With rising home ownership, wealth across the belt of heartlanders increased.  Families moved from kampongs and slums to HDB flats.  Many MPs would be familiar – if we asked the 1- to 3-roomers when they bought the flats, they would say, "in the 1960s, 1970s", and at least in Queenstown and Toa Payoh: "$6,200 for a flat".  Some of them cost a thousand dollars more if it was a corner unit.  That was in the 1960s.  By 1990, almost 90% of households owned their homes, which was a dramatic increase from 30% in 1970.  Not only more owned homes but the homes were bigger.  The percentage of households who lived in 1- to 3-room flats fell too – from 80% in 1970, it dropped to 25% in 2010.

     The rise in educational attainments was equally impressive. ensure that good teachers are spread out across the system, not only to the few top schools. We must ensure that all students have enrichment programmes or CCAs – which is what Ms Joscelin Yeo and Mdm Cynthia Phua were asking for – that can develop them to their full potential.  This, indeed, is exactly what MOE has been doing, especially in the past two decades or so.  Let me give you some specifics.

     What of the future?  Can we ensure the Singapore Story for the next generation?  Here, I want to caution what social mobility should not be about.  It cannot be about neglecting those with

abilities just because they come from middle-income homes or are rich.

 

 

It cannot mean holding back those who are able, so others can catch up.  This would be detrimental to the whole society.  I was quite happy, when PISA included Shanghai and they beat everybody.  They set a new standard.  More Chinese cities will be included and Members will be startled by how well the Chinese cities' students are performing.  If we look only within ourselves and think that we have arrived, it will be detrimental to the whole society.  We can and must provide opportunities to all and develop all students to their full potential.

Third, while MOE seeks to provide opportunities to all, no education system can replace the vital role that family and caregivers provide for an enriching learning environment. Here, we must dispel the notion that only rich parents can provide the right environment for their children to succeed.

We need to complete the messaging because otherwise you make people believe that you did not succeed because you were born in the wrong house, that you were not given enough tuition, you went to the wrong school – how many of you really believe that?  Honestly.

for.  Forty-four percent of those aged 25 to 39 today have university education.  Close to 50%.  I doubt if their children, your children, my children are likely to climb very much higher than 50% or even 60% (with university education).

schools and expand our programmes to develop diverse talents.  We will increase our subsidies to the lower- and middle-income students so that good education remains affordable for all.
